questions.text: The initial segment, just between the peak of the axon hillock and the initial (unmyelinated) segment of the axon is also known as the trigger zone for the action potential. Initiation of nerve impulse occurs at the initial segment because?

choices.text: It has a lower threshold than the rest of the axon

questions.solution:
From a functional point of view, neurons generally have four important zones:

  1. multiple local potential changes generated by synaptic connections are integrated in a receptor or dendritic zone.
  2. a site where propagated action potentials are generated (the initial segment in spinal motor neurons, the initial node of Ranvier in cutaneous sensory neurons);
  3. an axonal process that transmits propagated impulses to the nerve endings; and
  4. action potentials cause the release of synaptic transmitters at the nerve endings

In motor neurons, the initial segment is the portion portion of the cell with the lowest threshold for the production of an action potential (the portion of the axon at and just beyond the axon hillock)

questions.text: Electron transport chain has several complexes which throw the electrons from matrix to inter membrane space. The F1 portion of complex V has ATP synthase activity. What is the substance that blocks the transfer of ADP to ATP?
questions.solution:
COMPLEX V - Has 2 Portions

1. F0

  • Rolling gate
  • Proton Ion channel present on IMM
  • Attached to F1

2. F1

  • Protruding towards the mitochondrial matrix
  • Has ATP Synthase activity
  • Can convert ADP to ATP
  • ADP to ATP conversion inhibited by → OLIGOMYCIN
  • ADP to ATP transfer inhibited by → ATRACTYLOSIDE

ADP – ATP TRANSLOCASE

  • Present in IMM
  • Has 2 surfaces - Bigger & smaller
  • Transfer the substances by FLIP- FLOP MECHANISM
  • Takes ADP IN
  • ATRACTYLOSIDE - Inhibitor of ADP – ATP TRANSLOCASE

OLIGOMYCIN

  • Inhibitor of complex V
  • Not an uncoupler
  • It ligates F0 gate and closes it
  • Inhibits both oxidation & Phosphorylation

questions.text: A patient with right upper quadrant pain was diagnosed with gallstones and acute pancreatitis. Pancreas is supplied by various arteries. Arteria pancreatica magnum is one among them which is a branch of which vessel?
questions.solution:

  • Great artery to pancreas
  • Br. of splenic artery
  • Supplies pancreas

Splenic artery

  • Largest branch of celiac trunk
  • Runs torturously on superior border of pancreas, gives multiple branches into pancreas, which forms anastomoses with substances of pancreas

END ARTERIES TO SPLEEN

  • No further anastomoses

GASTRO DUODENAL ARTERY

  • Passes behind the 1st part of duodenal
  • Hepato pancreatic duct opens into 2nd part of the junction of fore gut & mid gut

  • Rt. gastro epiploic artery supplies greater curvature of stomach

questions.text: Among the following options, which is not a characteristics feature of facilitated diffusion?
questions.solution:
Facilitated diffusion is a carrier-mediated transport.

ATP is not consumed in this transport so does not require energy (option-3)

A conformational change in the carrier molecule causes the substance to be transported to the other side of the membrane.

Some models hypothesized for the carrier proteins ~ flip-flop model (transverse diffusion).

Vmax level (option-1) - the rate of diffusion cannot rise greater than this.

As it is transported through a carrier, it can be competitively inhibited (option-2)

Specific carriers available for specific diffusion of substances (option-4)

Saturability, Specificity and inhibition are the characteristics of the Facilitated diffusion

questions.text: The potential generated due to freely diffusible ion across a membrane is measured by which of the following equations?
questions.solution:
Nernst equation:

A freely diffusible ion, having different concentrations on either side of a membrane, would diffuse through the membrane and reach equilibrium.

Nernst equation, which describes the condition when an ion is in equilibrium across a membrane. Given values for [X]i and [X]o, X can be in equilibrium only when the voltage difference across the membrane equals the equilibrium potential (EX), also known as the Nernst potential.

At equilibrium, the chemical and electrical potential energy differences across the membrane are equal but opposite.

EMF (mV) = +/- 61/Z X log (C1/C2)

C1 and C2: are the concentrations of the ion on either side of the membrane.

Vm = Ex = -RT/ZxF ln (X)i/(X)

R = the gas constant; T = temperature in degrees Kelvin; ln = natural logarithm; [X]i = the concentration of X inside the cell

[X]o = the concentration of X outside the cell; Zx = the valence of charged molecules;

F = the Faraday constant

Vm = the membrane potential (Vm = Vi − Vo)

Goldman-Hodgkin-Katz(GHK) equation is an expanded Nernst equation. It calculates the potential created by more than one ion, when these ions move from their higher to lower concentrations.

Henderson Hasselbach equation: used to estimate the pH of a buffer solution

Gibbs donnan equillibrium: In the presence of a non- diffusable ion, the diffusable ion distributes themselves so that at equilibrium their concentrations ratios are equal

questions.text: Sleep spindles are seen in which phase of Sleep cycle?
questions.solution:
NREM Sleep

→ Further divided into four stages (stage 1-4)

→ Stage – 1 NREM

  • Light sleep (easy to awake a person)
  • EEG shows, loss of alpha waves
  • The predominance of theta waves

→ Stage -2 NREM

  • Maximum duration
  • Two typical findings
  1. Sleep spindles (bursts of regular waves, 13-15 Hz, 50 micro volts)
  2. K-complexes – high voltage spikes, seen intermittently

→ Stage – 3 NREM

  • Sleep deepens
  • Appearance of delta waves

→ Stage 4- NREM

  • Deep sleep
  • Predominance of delta waves

NREM sleep: there is pulsatile release of gonadotropins and growth hormone

  • BP, HR and RR Slows down

REM Sleep (Rapid eye movement sleep)

→ EEG – Beta waves and return of alpha waves is there

→ Rapid eye movements

→ Generalized loss of muscle tone

→ Increased rate of metabolism in brain

→ Increased HR, BP and RR

→ Associated with spontaneous penile erection

→ Dreams (can be recalled)

→ Paradoxical sleep (difficult to awake a person)

questions.text: A 26-year-old female with a history of using vaginal tampons presented to the OPD with a high fever, sore throat, dizziness and sunburn-like rash. She had a low BP on examination. Staphylococcal toxin was found to be responsible for this condition. Which of the following infections given below is not toxin-mediated?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of Staphylococcal TSS [toxic shock syndrome].

Other Toxin mediated illnesses of Staphylococcus:

1. Food poisoning :

  • Type A Enterotoxin is responsible for most of the cases of food poisoning.
  • Incubatory Period: 1-6 hr due to preformed toxin.
  • Site of action: The toxin stimulates the vagus nerve and vomiting center of the brain.
  • It also stimulates intestinal peristaltic activity.
  • Heat stable (not destroyed after heating food).
  • Detected by ELISA, Latex agglutination test and toxin gene detection by PCR.

2. SSSS (Staphylococcal Skin Scalded Syndrome):

  • due to exfolative toxins A & B.
  • Scalded skin syndrome (Nikolsky’s sign-epidermal layer separated)
  • Severe- Ritter disease (newborn), toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) (adult).
  • Milder- Pemphigus neonatorum, bullous impetigo.

3. TSS [toxic shock syndrome]: Multiorgan failure

  • due to TSS toxin (enterotoxin F).
  • Typically seen with history of usage of vaginal tampons.
  • it is a super antigen
  • non-MHC restricted
  • activates > 20% lymphocytes without being processed by antigen processing cells (APC).
  • leads to massive lymphokine release and shock.

questions.text: Sexual perversion where a man achieves sexual gratification by physically touching the private parts of a female but without intercourse is punishable under which section of Indian penal code?
questions.solution:
Sexual perversions

  • No Penetration but person achieves sexual gratification by any other methods (not by inter course)

1. Sadism

  • Person achieves sexual gratification by inflicting pain to the partner (Algolagnia)

2. Masochism:

  • Person achieves sexual gratification by suffering pain

3. Frotteurism

  • Person achieves sexual gratification by touching the private parts of a female
  • Punishable under 290 IPC

4. Fetichism

  • Person achieves sexual gratification with inanimate objects which are closely associated with females

5. Transvestism (eonism)

  • Person achieves sexual gratification by wearing the dress of opposite sex
  • Variant of fetichism

6. Exhibitionism

  • Person achieves sexual gratification by showing his private parts in public place
  • Punishable under 294 IPC
  • Flashing: Person Suddenly shows genialia
  • Mooning: Person Shows gluteal region
  • Streaking: Person Running Naked

7. Voyeurism or Scoptophilia or Peeping tom

  • Person achieves sexual gratification by watching the private acts.of a female
  • Punishable under 354 (C) IPC ( definition and punishment for voyeurism)

8. Triolism

  • Sexual activity with 3 persons

9. Necrophilia

  • Having sex with the dead body

10.Necrophagia

  • Eating the dead body

Both Necrophilia and Necrophagia are punishable under 297 IPC

11. Coprophilia

  • Person achieves sexual gratification by the sight / smell of feces
Natural sexual offence Unnatural sexual offence Sexual Perversion

Penis inserted into

→ Mouth

→ Animal

questions.text: Fibrinoid necrosis is seen in all of the following,except?
questions.solution:
Types of necrosis

1. Coagulative

  • It involves all the organs of body except CNS
  • Most common reason: hypoxia
  • There is formation of triangular structure called infarct: 3 “Tombsto0ne appearance”
  • Example: zenker’s degeneration seen in patient suffering from enteric fever

2. Liquefactive necrosis

  • Associated with abscess formation therefore associated with pyogenic infection it is seen in CNS
  • A/K/a colliquative necrosis

3. Caseous necrosis

  • “Cheese like appearance of Necrotic Material”
  • Example: Tuberculosis, systemic fungal infection e.g. (Histoplasma, Coccidioidomycosis0 and in bacterial infections like syphilis.

4. Fibrinoid necrosis

  • M: malignant hypertension due to damage to blood vessel as a result there is deposition of pinkish material in vessel wall
  • A: Aschoff body (histological finding in rheumatic heart disease)

Immune complexes damage the endothelial cells

↓

Associated with deposition of fibrin and fibrinoid material

questions.text: A 40 year old farmer presented with increased salivation, lacrimation and sweating. Physical examination revealed decreased heart rate and blood pressure. After few minutes, the patient died. What is the first site to start with autopsy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Cavity to start with

1. Poisoning cases → cranial cavity

2. New borns

→ Abdominal cavity

↓

To check the level of diaphragm (lower level → baby respired)

3. Asphyxial death

→ Cranial → Thorax → Abdominal → Neck

→ To achieve bloodless dissection of neck

4. Air embolism → Under water autopsy

  • Pericardium cut open & fluid with H2O
  • Then ventricle opened
  • In case of air embolism, air bubbles are seen

→ Pyrogallol test

  • Ventricle is aspirated by a syringe with pyrogallol test
  • In case of air embolism, color change in color.

5. Pneumothorax

→ Chest cavity opened first

  • Skin flap is reflected in thorax & filled with H2O
  • Then puncture the pleural cavity with a Sx blade
  • In case of pneumothorax, air bubbles will be seen

6. Normal cases → Thoracic cavity

questions.text: A 48 year old obese woman complains of fatigue, dizziness and sleepy during day time. It was noted that she was reported for snoring aloud during sleep by her husband. Also, she wakes up frequently in between sleep. Which of the following is not a long term complication in this patient?
questions.solution:
Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA)

  • Complete cessation of breathing for atleast 10 sec.
  • In deep sleep phase, all learned reflexes go away therefore, obstruction to airway

No mouth breathing (deep sleep phase)

↓

Apnea

↓

Co2 in ↑blood

↓

Stimulates chomorceptors in brain

↓

Brain wakes up resulting in partial return of learned reflexes

↓

Opens mouth, air graph in producing sound k/a snoring

  • Definition (Apnea) ≥90% drop in flow for 10 sec or longer,

+ ≥3% oxygen desaturation

Or An arousal

  • Hypopnea ≥ 30% drop in flow for 10 sec on longer

+ 3% oxygen desaturation

Or Resp. related arousal (RERA) {EEG / nasal flow limitation pattern}

  • Apnea- Hypopnoea Index (AHI) - Hourly rate of apneas plus hypopnoeas
  • AHI <5 → Normal
  • 5-15 → Mild OSAH
  • 16-30 → Mod. OSAH
  • >30 → severe OSAH

OSAHS

  • >5 obstructed Breaths / hr
  • And excessive daytime sleepiness not better explained by other factors
  • Or 2 or more of the following
  • Choking / gasping in sleep
  • Recurrent awakening
  • Unrefreshed sleep
  • Daytime fatigue
  • Impaired concentration

Complications

1. PAH

2. Right ventricular Hypertrophy (RVH)

T/t of OSA:

  • CPAP - Disadvantage: poor compliance [some Pt. may feel claustrophobic]
  • Mandibular advancement splint

Surgery - Depends on level of obstruction

  • Nasal surgery
  • Uvulopalotopharyngoplasty (UPPP)
  • Genioglossus advancement surgery
  • Robotic tongue base surgery

questions.text: A 10 months old male child suddenly drew up his legs and screamed with pain. This repeated periodically throughout the night interspersed with periods of quiet sleep. The child looked pale. He vomited and passed thin blood-stained stools. Physical examination showed palpable mass in the umbilicus. What is the appropriate management in a case of recurrence?
questions.solution:
Parts of intussusception

  • Intussusceptum- incoming segment
  • Intussuscepiens- receiving segment
  • Neck- narrowest part of intussusception
  • Apex - most prone to gangrene
  • Middle layer is most prone to gangrene because it is sandwiched between outer and inner layer and has two acute bends

Clinical features

  • At time of attack ­

- Child cries a lot, pulls legs towards abdomen ­

- Colicky pain ­

- Bilious vomiting (Multiple episodes)

  • In between attacks, patient is asymptomatic
  • After many attacks ­

- Passage of small amount of stools mixed with blood (Red current jelly appearance)

On examination

  • Sausage shaped mass in right lumbar region
  • Empty right iliac fossa known as Sign of dance

Investigation

  • Diagnostic + therapeutic - Enema (air > barium) Treatment
  • Air enema (Enema creates pressure by which there will be reduction of bowel back to normal)
  • For Recurrence - Air enema is repeated.
  • If recurrence occurs for the third time - indication for surgery i.e. Ileocolectomy + Ileo- transverse anastomosis

Radiological signs

Plain x- ray Barium enema Ultrasound
  • Meniscus sign
  • Target sign
  • Claw sign
  • Coiled spring sign
  • Target sign (transverse scan)
  • Pseudo kidney sign (longitudinal scan)

questions.text: A 30 year old patient presented with a growing mass in the neck. FNAC confirmed pleomorphic adenoma involving the deep lobe of parotid. Deep lobe parotidectomy was performed and after surgery, the patient noticed lower lip paralysis. Which of the following is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Types of Parotidectomy

1. Superficial or lateral or classical parotidectomy

  • For benign and malignant tumors involving superficiallobe
  • Salivary tissue lateral to facial nerve is removed

2. Deep lobe parotidectomy

  • For benign and malignant tumor involving deep lobe
  • Salivary tissue deep to facial nerve is removed

3. Total conservative parotidectomy

  • For benign and malignant tumor involving both superficial + deep lobe
  • All salivary tissue is removed. Facial nerve is preserved

4. Radical parotidectomy

  • For tumors invading facial nerve. All salivary tissue is removed + excision of facial nerve

5. Extended radical parotidectomy

  • Radical parotidectomy + removal of adjacent structures (mandible, temporal bone, muscles) Surgical Landmarks for facial nerve
  • S:Styloid process
  • T: Tragal pointer, Tympanomastoid
  • P: Posterior belly of digastric
  • Ra: Retromandibular vein

Complications of Parotidectomy

Facial nerve paresis/paralysis

  • Sensory abnormalities due to sacrifice of greater auricular nerve
  • Frey's syndrome
  • Parotid fistula

questions.text: A 35-year-old army personnel suddenly fall down while doing patrolling in Thar desert border in Rajasthan. He was immediately taken to a Military hospital and assessed by a Medical officer. On examination - he was unconscious and unresponsive and his pulse was impalpable. ECG was done and a diagnosis of PEA (Pulseless Electrical Activity) was made. Which of the following conditions is least likely to be the cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The 5 H and 5 T of pulseless electrical activity → PEA implies that electrical activity is seen on ECG but the pulse is absent. The leading cause of PEA is hypoxia secondary to respiratory failure (40-50% cases) and hypovolemia. Hydrogen ion depletion implies alkalosis whereas PEA occurs with acidosis.

H

  • Hypovolemia
  • Hypoxia
  • Hydrogen Ion (acidosis)
  • Hypo / Hyperkalemia
  • Hypothermia

T

  • Toxins
  • Tamponade
  • Tension Pneumothorax
  • Thrombosis (heart: acute, massive MI)
  • Thrombosis (lungs: massive PEE)

questions.text: A 27-year-old diabetic pregnant female delivered a macrosomic baby. On examination, it was found perineal tear has not involved anal sphincter. This will be classified as
questions.solution:
Classification Of Obstetric Anal Sphincter Injury (RCOG -2007)

First Degree: Injury to perinea! skin only

Second Degree: Injury to perineum involving perinea! body (muscles) but not involving the anal sphincter.

Third Degree: Injury to the perineum, involving the anal sphincter complex (both external and internal).

Fourth Degree: Injury to the perineum involving the anal sphincter complex (EAS and IAS) and anal epithelium.

(EAS = External anal sphincter: IAS = Internal anal sphincter)

questions.text: Mr. Ramesh, a business man has taken multiple bank loans from a nationalized bank and unable to make payments. He has been brought for psychiatric evaluation as recently he has been denying any memory of taking loans from the bank. Interestingly, all other memory functioning is pretty intact. This is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
Dissociative Amnesia:

Commonest clinical type of dissociative disorder.

Occurs mostly in late adolescence and young adults.

Severe psychological trauma, the patient temporarily and unconsciously shuts down the memory of the traumatic event

Circumscribed loss of traumatic memory is seen in these individuals

The other memories are intact and this cannot be explained by normal forgetting

Treatment:

Supportive psychotherapy, cognitive therapy, hypnosis.

Identify trauma related cognitive distortions and help the individual cope with adaptive behaviours

Drug assisted interview could be beneficial to elicit information- abreaction (not recommended in children)

option b - it's not fugue, as all other memory functions would also be disturbed in fugue.

questions.solution:
The image shows a child with erythema over cheeks with evidence of stomatitis.

The angiography reports show multiple aneurysms in course of left main coronary artery

Hence the diagnosis is Kawasaki disease.

Choice A is wrong as aspirin prevents the development of Myocardial infarction in a patient with Kawasaki disease.

Choice B is wrong as patients have bulbar congestion but absence of any discharge.

Choice D is wrong as patients develop a unilateral cervical lymphadenopathy with fever in initial part of illness.

Diagnostic Criteria for Kawasaki Disease

Fever persisting at least 5 days with the presence of at least 4 features out of 5:

-Conjunctivitis

-Rash

-Edema & erythema of palms & soles

-Adenopathy

-Mucosal involvement: Strawberry tongue

questions.text: A 5 year old child presented with shock. Despite administration of High flow O2, normal saline and Antibiotics, the shock was not reversed. The Blood pressure was low and it was a cold shock. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
CHILD WITH SHOCK

  • 0 min – Start high flow O2 and establish IV/IO access.

5 min

  • Push boluses of 20 ml/kg isotonic / NS upto 60 ml/kg, until perfusion improves or rales/ hepatomegaly appears.
  • Correct hypocalcaemia and hypoglycaemia.
  • Begin antibiotics

If shock not reversed, It is Fluid refractory shock.

15 min

  • Begin Ionotropes (Dopamine)
  • Obtain central vascular access and airway if needed.
  • If not improving, titrate Epinephrine (cold shock) or Nor epinephrine (warm shock).

If shock not reversed, It is Catecholamine resistant shock.

60 min

  • Begin Hydrocortisone
  • Monitor CVP in PICU
  • Maintain normal MAP – CVP & SCVO2 > 70 %
  • Maintain Hb > 10 gm/dl

  • If Shock not reversed, It is Persistent Catecholamine resistant shock.
  • Rule out Pericardial effusion and Pneumothorax.
  • If Shock not reversed, It is Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation.

questions.text: A 26 years old female was admitted to the hospital presented with abdominal pain for 1 week. The patient underwent several ultrasound scanning to rule out whether she had appendicular mass or ovarian mass. Based on the ultrasound scan result, she was diagnosed with an appendicular mass. Whar would be the most appropriate management for this case?
questions.solution:
Management of Appendicular Mass

  • If an appendix mass is present and the condition of the patient is satisfactory, the standard treatment is the conservative Ochsner-Sherren regimen.
  • This strategy is based on the premise that the inflammatory process is already localized and that inadvertent surgery is difficult and may be dangerous. It may be impossible to find the appendix and, a fecal fistula may form.
  • For these reasons, it is wise to observe a non-operative program but to be prepared to operate should clinical deterioration occur.
  • CECT abdomen should be performed & antibiotic therapy (Metronidazole + 3rd generation cephalosporin or single dose of ertapenem) should be given.
  • An abscess, if present, should be drained radiologically.
  • Temperature & pulse rate should be recorded 4-hourly and a fluid balance record maintained.
  • Clinical deterioration or evidence of peritonitis is an indication for early laparotomy.
  • Clinical improvement is usually evident within 24-48 hours.
  • Failure of the mass to resolve should raise suspicion of a carcinoma or Crohn’s disease.
  • Using this regimen, approximately 90% of cases resolve without incident.
  • The great majority of patients will not develop recurrence, and it is no longer considered advisable to remove the appendix after an interval of 6–8 weeks.

Criteria for stopping conservative treatment of an appendix mass

  • A rising pulse rate
  • Increasing or spreading abdominal pain
  • Increasing size of the mass

questions.text: A 24 hours old neonate developed difficulty feeding milk, dyspnea and crying most of the time. The baby looked irritable with a temperature of 32 degree Celsius, O2 sat of 80%. Blood culture detected presence of Acinetobacter, TLC – 4000 / mm3, ANC – 1800 / mm3, Micro ESR – 20 mm, CRP – 1 mg/dl, I-T ratio – 0.3. CSF studies were unremarkable. What is the treatment plan for this patient?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis of Neonatal Sepsis

  • Definitive Test → Blood Culture
  • Screening Test → Sepsis Screen
  • Sepsis Screen → High positive predictive value
  • Components → Any 2 out of 5 → +ve sepsis screen
  1. TLC [Total Leucocyte Count] → < 5000/mm3
  2. ANC (Absolute Neutrophil Count) →< 1800/mm3
  3. I-T ratio [Immature: Total neutrophil] →>0.2
  4. Micro ESR →>15 mm
  5. CRP [C-Reactive Protein]→> 1mg/dl has HighNegative Predictive Valve

Supportive Tests:

→ Blood glucose

→ CXR

→ Lumbar puncture & CSF study

Treatment of Neonatal sepsis

  1. Supportive Care

→ Shift to Nursery/ NICU

→ Start IV fluids

→ Maintain normal blood glucose

→ Maintain normal temperature

→ Monitor

2. Specific Treatment:

→ I.V Empirical broad Spectrum antibiotics

- [Inj. Ampicillin + Gentamicin]

+

Inj. Cefotaxime, if meningitis presents or suspected

Sepsis screen Blood culture CSF S/O meningitis Duration of Antibiotics
+ - - 1 week
± + - 2 weeks
± ± + 3 weeks

questions.text: A 35 year old male, chronic smoker for 10 years presented with double vision and paralysed facial muscles. Upon examination, there was no corneal reflex. → Tympanic / Horizontal segment 2nd genu (8 – 12mm)

→ Mastoid / vertical segment stylomastoid foramen

  • Extra temporal segment (15 – 20 mm)

questions.text: A newborn baby presented with symptoms of jaundice, vomiting and failure to thrive. A diagnosis of Galactosemia was made using Direct enzyme assay. What is the toxic component that damages the Kidney and Brain in this condition?
questions.solution:
GALACTOSEMIA

  • Autosomal Recessive
  • Deficiency of GALT (Galactose 1 PO4 Uridyl transferase) (MC), Galactokinase and Epimerase.

PATHOPHYSIOLOGY

  • Milk → Lactose → Glucose + Galactose
  • Galactose can’t get digested in body due to Enzyme Deficiency
  • Breast feeding is Contraindicated in Confirmed cases of Galactosemia
  • GALT Deficiency → Accumulation of Galactose-1-Phosphate which is Toxic to Kidney, Brain and Liver
  • Galactokinase Deficiency → Accumulation of Galactose and Galactitol which is Toxic to Eye

CLINICAL FEATURES:

  • Jaundice
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Seizures +/- MR
  • Cataract ( Might be the only manifestation of Galactokinase Deficiency )
  • Diarrhoea / vomiting
  • Failure to thrive
  • Sepsis with E.coli is common in children with Galactosemia

DUARTE VARIANT OF GALACTOSEMIA

  • Quite Common
  • Due to Single Amino Acid Substitution
  • 50 % of Normal Enzyme Activity Present
  • These Children usually remain Asymptomatic
  • No Clinical significance of this Condition

Diagnosis

  • Reducing Substances in Urine Positive (detected by Benedict’s Test)
  • Direct Enzyme assay
  • Prenatal Diagnosis is also Possible

TREATMENT

  • Avoid Milk and Milk Products · Use Lactose free formulas

questions.text: A 70 year old man with history of CHF presents with increased shortness of breath and leg swelling. ABG: pH 7.24, pC02 = 60 mmHg, P02 = 52, HC03 =27. Interpret:
questions.solution:
If there is acute respiratory acidosis, expected compensation is rise of HCO3 by 1 mEq/L for every 10 mm Hg rise of pCO2.

In this question change in pCO2 = 60 -40 = 20mmHg

Therefore, expected elevation in [HCO3] = 2 m Eq.

Since the actual HCO3- is close to the calculated HCO3, the diagnosis is respiratory acidosis

questions.text: Nada’s criteria is used for assessment of presence of congenital heart disease. Which of the following parameters does not indicate the possibility of congenital heart disease?
questions.solution:

questions.text: A 50 year old male presented to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal pain but but suddenly collapsed and died before receiving care. Autopsy showed several findings, including liver studded with numerous blood-filled lakes. Microscopically, these spaces were associated with vascular / spindle cell proliferation. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
PELIOSIS HEPATITIS

  • It is an uncommon disorder characterized by multiple, small, blood-filled sinuses
  • Commonly occurs in immunocompromised posttransplant patients, AIDS patients, and patients taking long-term steroids.

Etiology

  • Drugs causing it are androgens, azathioprine, tamoxifen, estrogen & vitamin A.

Diagnosis

  • Radiographically these lesions present as diffuse hypodense areas spread throughout the liver
  • CT and MRI show enhancement on early images, which may progress from central to peripheral on delayed imaging.

Treatment

  • The treatment for bleeding lesions has been angiographic embolization.

questions.text: A 65 year old patient with invasive ductal carcinoma had underwent mastectomy and chemotherapy with CAF therapy. What is the drug of choice for hormonal therapy for this pateint?
questions.solution:
• Drug of choice for hormone therapy in pre-menopausal patients - Tamoxifen
  • Drug of choice for Hormone therapy in post-menopausal patients - Aromatase inhibitors

Hormone therapy

  • Estrogen has positive effect on breast cancer cells
  • In hormone therapy either source of production of estrogen (ovary) is cut surgically or medically.
  • Surgical method of stopping estrogen production – Bilateral oophorectomy
  • Medical method of stopping estrogen production – Medical oophorectomy (block receptor of estrogen)
  • In premenopausal females, ovary is the main site of estrogen production
  • In postmenopausal females, estrogen is produced by peripheral aromatization from adipose tissues. (so, aromatase inhibitors are used in post-menopausal females).

Treatment

  • Ovarian ablation
  • Bilateral oophorectomy
  • LH/RH agonist (Goserelin, Leuprolide)
  • SERM (Selective estrogen receptor modulator)

- Tamoxifen

- Raloxifene

  • Aromatase Inhibitors (useful only in post-menopausal females)

- Non-steroidal (Letrozole, Anastrozole)

- Steroidal (Exemestane)

  • Anti-estrogens

- Fulvestrant

  • Progestins

- Megestrol

- Medroxy progesterone acetate

questions.text: A 60 year old woman presented with decreased oral intake, nausea, vomiting, and right upper quadrant pain that started two days prior to presentation. The patient also had a history of 2 days of fever & chills. On examination, she had icteric sclera mental status was abnormal with signs of septic shock. What is the most probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The given patient has the classical symptoms - Reynold’s pentad which suggests that this is a case of Cholangitis

Cholangitis

  • Ascending bacterial infection of the biliary ductal system with obstruction
  • MC cause of acute cholangitis is choledocholithiasis
  • MC organisms present in the bile in patients with cholangitis: E. coli; Klebsiella pneumonia; Streptococcus faecalis, & Bacteroidesfragilis

Etiology

  • Choledocholithiasis (MC)
  • Biliary-enteric anastomotic strictures
  • Benign strictures
  • Cholangiocarcinoma and periampullary cancer

Clinical Features

  • Characterized by Charcot’s triad: Abdominal pain + jaundice + fever
  • Cholangitis may be either self-limited or toxic with severe illness, including jaundice, fever, abdominal pain, mental status changes and hypotension (Reynold’s pentad).

questions.text: A 30 year old male was brought to emergency department after a road traffic accident. He was complaining of watery discharge from nose. However, the discharge was clear with no blood stain in it. What is the investigation of choice in this patient?

CSFRhinorrhea

  • MC site:- fracture Cribriform plate of Ethmoid
  • Sniff test: Cannot sniff back

  • MRI – T2 weighted images (Can't see both #the CSF at once)
  • CT cisternography (Can see both #and the CSF)

Management - Traumatic

  • Conservative Management
  • Prophylactic Antibiotics (Wait for 7 days) Acetazolamide

questions.text: A 40 year old, right handed male presented to the ER with right upper arm pain. It was noted that he was a member of an amateur baseball team. Just prior to arrival he threw a ball and immediately felt a pop and sharp pain in his right upper arm. Following this trauma, which hormone is not released?
questions.solution:
Metabolic and Neuroendocrine Response to Trauma or Surgery

  • Injury Phase (Phase of catabolism)

- Begins at the time of injury and lasts for 2-5 days

- Phase of hypermetabolism

- Stress hormones (cortisol, catecholamines, and glucagon) and volume control hormones (renin-angiotensin, aldosterone, and ADH) are increased. This leads to proteolysis, lipolysis, hyperglycemia and wound healing despite negative nitrogen balance.

  • Turning Point: Transient period marked physiologically by turning off of the neuroendocrine response and clinically by the appearance of getting well.
  • Early Anabolic Phase: Marked by a gain in muscular strength or positive nitrogen balance
  • Late Anabolic Phase: Marked by a gain in weight and body fat or positive caloric balance

questions.text: A 45 year old female patient was rushed to the hospital after being involved in a house explosion with a resultant fire. A third degree circumferential burn in the arm and forearm region was noted. Which of the following is most important for monitoring?
questions.solution:
Escharotomies

  • When deep second and third-degree burn wounds encompass the circumference of an extremity, peripheral circulation to the the limb can be compromised.
  • Development of generalized edema beneath a non-yielding eschar impedes venous outflow and affects arterial inflow to the distal beds.
  • This can be recognized by numbness and tingling in the limb and increased pain in digits.
  • Arterial flow can be assessed by determination of Doppler signals in the digital arteries and the palmar and plantar arches in affected extremities.
  • Capillary refill can also be assessed.
  • Extremities at risk are identified either on clinical examination or by measurement of tissue pressures >40 mm Hg.
  • These extremities require escharotomies (release of the burn eschar by incising the lateral and medial aspects of the extremity).

On barium study

  • Mushroom sign
  • Double track sign
  • Caterpillar sign- because of gastric hyperperistalsis

  • In CHPS = because of continuous vomiting & gastric hyper peristalsis there will be increased gastric residue

questions.text: A 35 year old male presented with nausea and vomiting. An ultrasound of the abdomen revealed hyper echoic areas in the liver. questions.solution:
Hemangioma - M/C benign lesion of the liver

Radiological finding

  • On USG → hyper echoic area
  • On CECT → Delayed centripetal enhancement after initial peripheral nodular enhancement
  • On T2W - MRI → light bulb appearance

Hemangioma showing Delayed centripetal enhancement after initial peripheral nodular enhancement

Light bulb appearance

  • On MRI Liver - Hemangioma
  • On MRI Abdomen - Pheochromocytoma
  • On DW-MRI Brain - Acute infarct
  • On Shoulder Radiograph - Posterior dislocation of shoulder

Few important Enhancement patterns

  • Hemangioma → Delayed centripetal enhancement
  • HCC → derives major blood supply from Hepatic artery
  • HCC → Has early arterial enhancement with rapid washout
  • Meningioma → Early enhancement, delayed washout → Mother in law" sign

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Disease, Except?

choices.text: Extrarenal manifestations include Intracranial aneurysm, hepatic cyst
Cardiovascular complications are the leading cause of mortality.
Mortality is very high, and patients succumb to death within 10 years of life

questions.solution:
Chr 16 PKD1 gene defect → Polycystin 1 protein affected - Chr 4 PKD2 gene defect → Polycystin 2 protein affected

  • Multiple cysts are present both in the medulla and cortex.
  • Renomegaly and progressive development of cyst occur.
  • Development of bleeding in the cyst can occur and which can cause flank pain.
  • High penetrance, variable expression (expressed in every generation but presentation will be variable)

Clinical features:

  • Usual age of presentation = 30 – 45 yrs

1. Flank pain (M/C) [Can be due to stone formation, bleeding in cyst → Gerota fascia stretch]

  • Isolated Hematuria is not a feature of ADPKD. In contrast, gross hematuria will develop from rupture of the cyst, that communicates with the collecting system.

2. UTI incidence ↑: Higher chance of pyelonephritis (Tenderness in Costovertebral junction)

3. Stones incidence ↑ [M/C stone in polycystic kidney = Urate stones) (M/C kidney stone otherwise=Oxalate stones)

4. Rarely Can develop RCC: B/L multicentric (Severity is more)

5. GFR ↓ because cysts are progressively developing: Renin concentration­ ↓ Retention of Na → HTN, resulting in daily Headache & uremia if detected late.

Extra renal manifestation (ADPKD):

1 Liver cyst (Lined by biliary endothelium) M/C extra renal manifestation Usually asymptomatic Pancreas cyst Spleen cyst

2. CNS

a. Berry aneurysm → Subarachnoid hemorrhage, warning leaks → Excruciating headache.

b. Arterial dolichoectasia → Malformation in the vascular supply of brain – predisposes patient to arterial dissection and can cause Stroke manifestation.

c. Arachnoid cyst

3. CVS

a. Mitral valve prolapse - Mid systolic clicks, late systolic murmur

b. Mitral regurgitation

c. Tricuspid regurgitation Pansystolic murmur

4. GIT → Colonic diverticulosis (Can present as constipation) (Lungs are usually spared in ADPKD) ADPKD → Has High Penetrance (Expressed in almost every generation) and Variable Expression.

MC cause of Death is Hypertension Related Complications.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presents at 17 weeks for antenatal evaluation as she had a history of delivering a baby with Downs syndrome. Which of the following is the next investigation of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
Because there is a past history of Down syndrome, a confirmatory test should be done.

Amniocentesis and karyotyping are the best choice here. It is generally done around 16–18 weeks and gives confirmatory results.

The triple marker is only a screening test and not a confirmatory test.

USG can pick up soft tissue markers of Down syndrome, but it is not confirmatory, and USG can be normal in a fetus with Down syndrome.

If the same patient presents at 11–12 weeks, then the answer is CVS and karyotyping.

questions.text: False perception in the absence of any stimulus is an example of?

questions.text: A patient presented with a non insidious onset of mid abdominal pain. Examination revealed palpable abdominal mass. Past history revealed that the patient has a failed kidney. What is the investigation of choice for diagnosing this patient?

  • MC causes of AAA - Atherosclerosis [ MC cause of Renal artery Aneurism – Medial Fibroplasia > Atherosclerosis ]
  • MC symptom in AAA - Chronic vague abdominal pain / back pain (because location of aneurysm is retroperitoneal)
  • MC & lethal complication of aneurysm - Rupture
  • Most important predictor for rupture - Width / Diameter
  • MC site of rupture - Left retroperitoneum

Triad of AAA

  • Sudden onset of midabdominal or flank pain
  • Shock seen only in 1/3rd of cases
  • Pulsatile abdominal mass

Investigations

  • X-ray - Eggshell pattern of calcification
  • Investigation of choice for screening of abdominal aortic aneurysm - USG
  • Investigation of choice for diagnosis & planning repair of abdominal aortic aneurysm - CT
  • Investigation of choice for diagnosis & planning repair of abdominal aortic aneurysm in patients of renal failure - MRI

Indications of surgery in AAA

  1. Diameter ≥ 5.5 cm / ≥ 5cm in females
  2. Symptomatic aneurysm
  3. Rate of expansion >1cm/year
  4. Atypical aneurysm (pseudoaneurysm, dissecting aneurysm, saccular aneurysm )

Management

questions.text: A 35 years old male with papillary carcinoma in the thyroid with a nodule < 3 cm confined to neck with 2 lymph nodes palpable in the neck along with lung micro-metastasis. How will you stage this according to AJCC 8th edition?
questions.solution:
Age <55 years

  • any T, any N, M0 – stage 1
  • Any T, any N, M 1 – stage 2

Age ≥55 years

  • Stage 1 - T1/T2, N0, M0
  • Stage 2 - T1/T2, N1, M0 and T3a/T3b, Any N, M0
  • Stage 3 - T4a, Any N, M0
  • Stage 4a - T4b, Any N, M0
  • Stage 4b - Any T, Any N, M1

Primary tumor (T)

Tx = Primary tumor cannot be assessed

T0 = No evidence of primary tumor

T1 = Tumor ≤ 2cm in greatest dimension limited to the thyroid

  • T1a = Tumor ≤ 1 cm in greatest dimension limited to the thyroid
  • T1b = Tumor >1cm but ≤ 2 cm in greatest dimension limited to the thyroid

T2 = Tumor >2cm but ≤ 4 cm in greatest dimension limited to the thyroid

T3 = Tumor >4 cm limited to the thyroid, or gross extrathyroidal extension invading only strap muscles

  • T3a = Tumor >4cm limited to the thyroid
  • T3b = Gross extrathyroidal extension invading only strap muscles (sternohyoid, sternothyroid, thyrohyoid or omohyoid muscles) from a tumor of any size

T4 = Includes gross extrathyroidal extension beyond the strap muscles

  • T4a = Gross extrathyroidal extension invading subcutaneous soft tissues, larynx, trachea, esophagus, or recurrent laryngeal nerve from a tumor of any size
  • T4b = Gross extrathyroidal extension invading prevertebral or encasing the artery or mediastinal Vessels from a tumor of any size

Regional lymph nodes (N)

NX = Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed

N0 = No evidence of locoregional lymph node metastasis

  • N0a = One or more cytologically or histologically confirmed benign lymph nodes
  • N0b = No radiologic or clinical evidence of locoregional lymph node metastasisN1= Metastasis to regional nodes
  • N1a = Metastasis to level VI or VII (pretracheal, paratracheal, or prelaryngeal/ Delphian, or upper Mediastinal) lymph nodes. This can be unilateral or bilateral disease
  • N1b = Metastasis to unilateral, bilateral, or contralateral lateral neck lymph (levels I, II, III, IV, or V) or retropharyngeal lymph nodes

Distant Metastasis (M)

M0 = No distant metastasis

M1 = Distant metastasis

BIOFILM formation

Tobramycin nebulization to prevent primary colonization by these microorganism.

  • Endocrine pancreas also damaged - cell damage → Type 1 DM
